headline.main: Hospital Breaks Ground for Cardiac Center

docs.abstract: New York-Presbyterian Hospital breaks ground for cardiac center on campus of Columbia University Medical Center in Manhattan; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital broke ground yesterday on a cardiac center that hospital officials said would greatly expand its research capabilities and contribute to battling cardiovascular diseases. The hospital is regarded as a leader in procedures like robotically assisted open-heart surgery.
docs.snippet: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital broke ground yesterday on a cardiac center that hospital officials said would greatly expand its research capabilities and contribute to battling cardiovascular diseases.

headline.main: Reality TV for Children, With Better Health as the Prize

docs.abstract: Reality mini-series Let's Just Play Go Healthy Challenge will follow four youths age 11 to 14 as they try to create healthier lifestyles; mini-series takes place against backdrop of nationwide explosion in obesity rates among adults and children; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Chris, an 11-year-old from San Francisco, is a fitness buff and athlete whose perspective on the galloping rates of childhood obesity mostly comes from what he sees and knows. ''A lot of kids who are younger are obese,'' said Chris, a sixth grader who plays basketball, skateboards and lobbies his middle school for better food choices. ''They feel uncomfortable with themselves. They don't really talk to anyone. They just sit down and eat their lunch.''
docs.snippet: Nickelodeon's "Let's Just Play Go Healthy Challenge" takes place against the backdrop of a nationwide explosion in obesity rates among adults and children.

keywords.value: LET'S JUST PLAY GO HEALTHY CHALLENGE (TV PROGRAM)
keywords.name: creative_works

headline.main: Field Guide to the Grocery Aisles

docs.abstract: New book What to Eat by nutritionist Marion Nestle helps readers determine how to make their meals healthier by choosing fruits and vegetables and reading labels; photo (M)
docs.section_name: Arts; Dining and Wine; Education; Books
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a well-known professor of nutrition writes a book titled ''What to Eat,'' it is fair to wonder what she likes for lunch. Recently, the professor, Marion Nestle, a confessed foodie, chose roasted beets, assorted squashes with hazelnut vinaigrette, roasted brussels sprouts with chèvre and caramelized walnuts.
docs.snippet: When a well-known professor of nutrition writes a book titled "What to Eat," it is fair to wonder what she likes for lunch.

headline.main: The Beating Pulse of the 18th Floor

docs.abstract: Article describes day in varied offices on typical floor of Empire State Building, which is celebrating its 75th anniversary; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE voice of Mike Gallagher boomed, godlike, in the air. Red lights flickered on a broadcasting console at the radio studio. ''Hello? Hello?'' he said. ''One, two, three.''
docs.snippet: Radio days, poetry-fueled nights and, in between, a little Organic Tummy Joy. This is a typical floor in the Empire State Building.

headline.main: Men Join the Migration to the Halls of Diet and Fitness

docs.abstract: Article on rise in number of men who are joining diet centers and health spas in effort to learn how to eat less, exercise more and control weight; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: JOE ROBERTS owns a demanding import and export business in Miami, but in March he took time off to travel to a diet center and learn how to eat less, exercise more and control his weight. ''There's no question I overeat,'' he said.
docs.snippet: As long as they can pay the fees, men who want to trim their waistlines can begin to do so at a health spa with no worries about seeming unmanly.

docs.abstract: Carlos Eduarte letter contends that not all baby boomers a
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: After reading your article, one would get the impression that there isn't a problem with obesity in this country. The baby boomers described cannot be a monolithic group because there are many people born in the time period who also suffer from chronic health issues, many of which were brought on by a lifestyle that is the polar opposite of that described by those obsessed with fitness. Is there some kind of common characteristic that led the particular group studied to embrace a lifestyle of fitness? Carlos Eduarte Minneapolis
docs.snippet: To the Sports Editor:     After reading your article, one would get the impression that there isn't a problem with obesity in this country. The baby boomers described cannot be a monolithic group because there are many people born in the time period...

headline.main: On the Mound, Big Bodies Eat Up the Innings

docs.abstract: Benjamin Hoffman Keeping Score column discusses relevance of size to baseball player's pitching performance; photos (M)0
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Kansas City Royals announced in spring training that they were sending the promising starter Runelvys Hernandez home because he had gained too much weight, it raised a question: Can a pitcher be too big? Hernandez, who just turned 28, is listed at 6 feet 1 and 250 pounds. Using a measure of weight distribution called body mass index, or B.M.I., Hernandez rates a 33, which puts him over the adult obesity threshold of 30 as defined by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. If reports that he had shot up to 280 pounds were correct, then Hernandez's B.M.I. had reached a hefty 36.9.
docs.snippet: While other sports have a need for players with large body mass, size is another matter when it comes to pitchers. And that makes it hard to explain the pattern of success and durability with large pitchers.
